text: Unbox Therapy so watching this has really opened and eye opening for who ever watches this, but I can‚Äôt help any and don‚Äôt want hate on this because everyone is different it just hasn‚Äôt really hasn‚Äôt changed my mind and that‚Äôs just because I pick the the phone that my eyes see it‚Äôs never a iPhone as they don‚Äôt shine I had an LG G5 and was brilliant and then last year I picked the Hawaii P20 pro as it has and change in style from anything else to me, the back if you pick the changing colour theme is super shiny from purple to blue, I fell in love with it plus I have always used gmail and google which this phone was brilliant at plus storage and plenty of room for music to play anything I want on my speakers, the cameras where a bonus but this it what I used for photos, chuck away cameras, old school and you get a perfect picture every time, beats my phone and the photos of me as a baby are about 22 years old now still look better quality then the Hawaii, eye opening right, no not really everyone all high end company are at that moment of trying to create the impossible a perfect picture but the old company are just chilling like Motorola M the gold flip up phone, bring it back I had that and have no idea where it is now as moved a lot and things get lost, just hope you get what I mean, you can spend 2000 pounds or dollars in a phone that is like the old phone, super protective, simple, calls, texts, and just some simple games or you can just change it by the push of a button to nothing but calls or texts, how simple but why the expense, old company‚Äôs that have sat and watched for probably 15 plus years get involved which with the change of people and what we really want, there coming back and some have made it to the expensive side and rich old people love it because of how simple they are, that‚Äôs why, I would by the last phone you unboxed the lever one, love watches and that had it bloody allÔªø

well done MKBHD! let users decide whats GOOD.
thats what i dont like about a lot of youtubers and written reviews, its always experts declaring the "universal truth"  that A is better than B.
the biggest lesson here is that the general public wants something different than what most "experts" think they want, or think they KNOW is best.
this applies to companies as well, blindly following experts both internally and externally can really lead you astray, you gotta do user surveys and really work closely with the community!Ôªø

author: So So

text: I don't understand... why people care so much about a phone camera??? realistically... what kind of pictures people taking with their smartphones? They certainly not taking world class, award winning photos. Most of the time it's a dick pic or a photo of a document... like... who the hell cares about a phone camera that much? it's good enough already. Phones will never be better than a full frame camera (because of sensor size). If you want to take world class pictures - get a camera. If you want to take a picture of a document or a selfie - get whatever smartphone on the market. It'll do the job just fine. No one is going to notice the difference on instagram, facebook or twitter anyways.Ôªø

text:
3:43 The public had the same photos at their disposal BUT everyone uses different phones with different screens (LCD or OLED) each with their own unique color gamut/white balance differences etc out of the box and each of the head to head photos will look different across everyone's phone.

Also, there are people who most likely compared the photos via looking at them on a tv screen (VA panel, IPS, OLED), a gaming monitor (TN, VA, IPS), a professional color accurate monitor, etc and they voted on their picks accordingly.

The video was a FUN yet BASIC test on general consumer preference but ultimately those too many variables are what flawed the end result of the blind test severely.Ôªø

author: fistinair

text: I'm curious why NO ONE mentions the fact that you can have at least 90% of the Pixel 3 quality with GCam on the POCOPHONE F1. Especially with the last update, you have everything (including the amazing Night Sight), and the buffer issue is completely gone. Really, when you factor that in, what REAL excuse can you find to justify a Pixel 3? We're talking at the very LEAST 2.5 X the price, if not even 3X. You can literally get 3 POCOs for ONE Pixel 3. Oh, and you get a DIRAC, high quality (really AMAZING audio) 3.5 mm headphone jack to boot! An SD card expansion slot too. Oh, a 4000 mAh battery too, compared to 2915 mAh on the Pixel 3. And accurate, INSTANTANEOUS facial recognition, even in pitch black darkness, as compared to no such feature on the Pixel 3. OH, and liquid cooling (it actually DOES work, it's incredible). OHHH, AND 6GB of RAM instead of 4GB on the Pixel 3. AND the ability to unlock your bootloader officially, and put the Pixel 3 software (or Lineage OS or anything you want) on it. So far, the only real plus sides of the Pixel are the special visual core chip (that helps the phone consume less battery when taking pictures), and the OLED screen, as compared to the perfectly good (but IPS LCD screen) on the POCO. This phone was the most hyped up phone of 2018, and for good reason. In my opinion, it wasn't hyped up enough, and people still preferred to go the BRAND way and buy an iPhone, a Pixel, S9, or a Huawei. Which is I guess fine when you can afford it. But what bugs me the most is that people who can't afford the flagships still went on to buy the entry level phones from those brands, which UTTERLY SUCK in comparison to Xiaomi. I mean... picking up a Samsung J6 over a Mi A2 Lite ?! Sometimes I think ignorant consumers deserve what's coming to them.Ôªø

Bottom line is this.
Buy what you require and want in the context of what you need your phone to do and want you want it to be capable of.

If you want or require a higher end camera on a phone then buy it.
If you want or require a cheap phone with an okay camera that will be more than fine for social media, then buy it.

The argument between haters and fanboys needs to fucking stop, because the people arguing are clearly the most ignorant and idiotic of anyone involved with tech.
There are discussions to be had, but argument about this stuff solves nothing.Ôªø

author: Christian √ñhrn

text: Agree. Incredibly good phone. I broke my initial pocophone that I paid 328 euros for and that was the 64gb version. I just received a new one and it's a 128gb model and paid 281 euros. The two combined cost me less than a Samsung note 9 and around the same as a oneplus 6T. That's incredible value really. The camera is actually supposed to be it's weakest component according to many critics. I never agreed and the camera is even better when you port the Google pixelcam apk on to the phone after unlocking the bootloader. It's not pretty. In fact the notch is very ugly but you get over it when you realise the sheer horsepower it possesses. It's incredibly quick and it can support the most demanding games as well with no problems. The sound quality is even great. I'm fascinated to see what they do with the pocophone f2. It's a difficult act to follow.Ôªø
author: Sean Q

text: @Sean Q It has what i need and want from a phone for sure! Good battery, good camera & they update often... and for the notch yeah maybe, but it came iin the era of the notch. Next will prob have a hole punch, and then they are there again as a samsung killer!Ôªø
author: Christian √ñhrn

text: @Christian √ñhrn rumour is that they will revamp the design but stick with the snapdragon 845 to save costs. I honestly wouldn't mind that. These are rumours but people are suggesting an amoled screen, ois and nfc may be added as well as a metal build but they'll stick with last year's sd845 cpu. That's still an amazing cpu. It's not the sd855 but still better than 90 percent of the processors out there. Totally agree. It's a revolutionary phone. It's another level to the oneplus in terms of a flagship killer. Oneplus 5t is still more expensive than the pocophone and the op6 and op6t are almost twice the price if not more.Ôªø
author: Sean Q

text: I remember voting in the finals thinking how the hell did this (what was revealed to be the poco phone) even get here? But they did bring up a good point. Most of our photo sharing is on Instagram or Twitter and for a lot of people, just Instgram stories or Snapchat. So as long as out of camera looks good enough, they're happy with it. Which I guess was why HTC was very willing to forego resolution to having better low light performance without hdr or long exposures which works out better for indoors or for parties. But still though, manufacturers still need to keep working on a good enough auto mode that is easy to use and doesn't just do whatever it wants to like enabling portrait bokeh when taking a landscape shot in auto mode stares at NokiaÔªø

text: I think the test really doesn't count in my opinion because the compression of social media platforms like Instagram especially degrade the quality to a default set point. I took some amazing shots in 4k on Spiderman PS4 and literally the second I posted it to Instagram, just because of the fact that the photo was above a certain resolution, it made it look just alright. I also noticed if you post a photo with a resolution closer to that cutoff point, it won't look as bad as the 4k photo for some reason.Ôªø

text:
iPhone XS, P20 and Mate 20 are in fact the top 3 smartphone cameras that money can buy today. 

But keep in mind that DxO mark doesn‚Äôt take enough into consideration. Although the Huawei phones have a higher rating, DxO mark doesn‚Äôt take the 4k60 capabilities of iPhone into consideration. They don‚Äôt take the viewfinder accuracy into consideration, or the characteristic of the stabilization, or the 3D depth layers (for computational bokeh), or the dynamic range into consideration. If they did, iPhone would have the same or better rating as the Huawei phones. 

Technically, the Huawei phones have inferior camera systems in them, but they do offer a 3x telephoto zoom lens. That ups the overall score, coupled with the fact that DxO mark just doesn‚Äôt have enough categories to consider the new and debuting camera technologies that Apple develops.Ôªø

author: Miguel Diaz

text:
1. MKBHD should have put the correct title for his video => "Best camera for social media - The blind test".  With this title, it would have been clear that people voted by watching the photos on social media (=on a small screen without seeing the full resolution)
2. MKBHD should have included photos that emphasize on the dynamic range (for example a sky with sun and clouds or shots of places with shadows).
3. MKBHD should have included low light shots.
So he intentionally or unintentionally made these 3 mistakes and these mistakes brought the wrong results => The wrong results may affect the decisions of smartphone manufacturers and lead them to downgrade the cameras by applying oversharpening, oversaturation and over exposure => In my opinion, if he truly cares a lot about the  smartphone cameras, he should have removed the video so as to not mislead the consumers.Ôªø

author: Heavy Box

text: No disrespect, but I think you guys aren't looking at the whole picture (no pun intended) from a BUSINESS point of view... Companies like Samsung and Apple are fully aware that people tend to like bright and colorful pictures.. Even if it's shot on a cheaper phone and camera.. BUT that DOESN'T sell phones to the typical consumer. The TYPICAL consumer looks at the specs on paper. Statistics show that they go for the "higher numbers" you can say. THAT is what sells the phones to the majority. The salesman at Bestbuy can say "well this IPhone camera has this amount of megapixels and the Blackberry ONLY has this.. and that.. and etc..." and your average consumer (which is the bulk of these companies money) picks what's best on paper.. It's simple marketing.Ôªø

text: There‚Äôs definitely lots of confounding errors in his experiment. Subjectivity from himself and the general public of what they consider ‚Äògood‚Äô like how Lue pointed out, plus mkbhd‚Äôs own bias in choosing the phots to be posted. So it wasn‚Äôt fully blind, but mostly blind. And someone else should‚Äôve taken all of these photos and posted all the pictures then have Marques look at them without Marques uploading them himself. But a solid experiment nonetheless, but should be noted for people that the ‚Äòbest‚Äô camera is mostly a fallacy when it comes down to a factor to buy or notÔªø

author: TheLionPrince

text: @Abhi Patel So I'm stubborn for pointing out that their testing methodology was flawed? I care about picture quality and compression because I'm not utterly clueless, however I don't care what random people on Instagram or Facebook think is or isn't a good picture. No, what the test proved is that flawed methodology judged by people who mostly know nothing about camera quality will produce weird results, I'll stick with DxOMark if I need to know about camera quality not a bunch of clueless social media users.Ôªø
author: Skullet

text: @TheLionPrince Don't bother waiting on me just visit DxOMark, why would you take the word of random people on social media who mostly know nothing about picture quality.Ôªø
author: Skullet

text: @Kongkon Sarmah Agreed, that way it takes a bunch of random elements out of the equation. Alternatively they could have just referred to DxOMark or another organisation that actually know something about cameras instead of random people on social media.Ôªø
author: Skullet

text: @Skullet Guess who is interacting with the pictures taken by all the good and bad cameras? 'a bunch of clueless social media users', or whatever you call want to call them. This is a community and this is how they perceive things. You being knowledgeable about picture quality and what not is your personal trait which is respectable but I am willing to bet that if you participated in the whole process, you would ultimately end up picking the pictures taken on the cheaper brands like all the others. The whole thing was a sample of like a couple tens of thousands of people, ( It is defs more btw like closer to 50k, i cant remember ), and most likely there is at least one person who is way more educated than you who accepted the results for what they are and acknowledged the fact that the cheaper pictures were ultimately more appealing. If that one person did not have a problem, why do you? (further adding to the point that you are stubborn)Ôªø
author: Abhi Patel

text: @Abhi Patel I don't judge the quality of a camera or anything else based on the opinions of random social media users though, if I want to know about camera quality I use reputable organisations who specialise in that field. I definitely wouldn't have picked the cheaper brands unless they were objectively better which they aren't, adding artificial blur or over saturating picture's isn't something I want from a camera. You went off on a weird irrelevant tangent with that hypothetical one person thing, I think we'll have to agree to disagree as this is my final post on the matter.Ôªø

text: The problem with this question is that most people don't give two shit about anything in the photo but the colours, if you just make them vibrant, make the shadows a bit darker and highlights a bit lighter people will go crazy for those. People don't care about the framing, about the material in the picture, about the position of stuff in the picture, most people don't even understand the rule of thirds. In most cases people will see the subject and try to have it in the centre of the image. And the only other things people know how to do, is over do the bokeh.Ôªø

text:
This shit needs to stop. I prefer Android, and even at $1000 price range, I would find the most absurd Android phone before looking at iPhone. 

But you people just won't shut the fuck up. Have you seen iPhone's single and multicore performance? Without a doubt nothing Android-supported touches it. But who shits a fuck, a fast cpu is a fast cpu. But what about GPU? notebookcheck ranks the Apple A12 GPUs above even the Snapdragon 630. And fuck, man I wish Android had monstrous graphics power but it fucking doesn't. We're not gonna pass Apple because they're richer and better at it. But something Apple will never win at is with pricing. You can buy Snapdragon 845 devices for $300-$400. You will never find the $750 XR touch this price as long as its relevant with its A12 bionic.

So no, specs are not better on Android lol. it's literally out there for you to see, if not on notebookcheck, then geekbench. I know how you Android geeks love numbers.Ôªø

author: DOJO MOJO

text:
@Jason Ray Oh the same old argument. One that has been used about Mac's not getting viruses etc for decades. Simply put it's not true. Security has little to do with any of it. It all comes down to market share, unique hardware, updating software and user created access.

When you want to try to exploit something (unless you're an idiot) you don't choose the OS/Hardware that <10% of the world uses. You go for the one that >80% do. This is the same for phones. Since Mac's have been running the same Intel Chips as PC's, for 10+ years now, they don't have the old advantage they used to. Oh and no the A11/12 chips (in the phones) aren't safe because of this either. They are ARM architecture just like Snapdragons etc. Just look at what happened during the Meltdown and Spectre vulnerabilities debacle last year. So it all comes down to user stupidity and both have plenty. The one leg up you could give Apple is Security patches being pushed. But this isn't on Android either. The Essential/Nexus/Pixel get them just like iPhone, "insert other Android phone manufacturer here" just insist on skinning their devices so the updates take a while.Ôªø

author: Hill Lam

text: @Hill Lam you are a typical ignorant Chinese. Let me teach you some. In 5g tech, there are 2 kinds. The first being 3.5 GHz and the second one being 28 GHz. In order to build 5G network one needs both. 3.5 GHz one is slower but covers much wider range and the 28 GHz one is much faster but covers much shorter range. 3.5 one is built across the nation whereas 28 one is usually built in cities. Now, Huawei is better at 3.5 and that is technologically easier than 28 one. But since Huawei focused on 3.5 one primarily, it has capability of manufacturing. In fact, Samsung has better tech than huawei in 28 one. It's a matter of time before others catch up Huawei in production capability since it's technically easier. In conclusion, you are wrong. Huawei's 5g tech is not faster it covers wider range and production capability.Ôªø
